Body: Description: Host lists are being updated by discovery queries, but the total host management list contains many outdated targets.  Some Host lists, which appear to be dynamic contain targets that are decommissioned.
Next Steps Updated: Manually clean up Host Management

Steps to Reproduce Updated: Identify decommissioned hosts in Host Management
Run Host Discovery against target environment
See decommissioned hosts remain in Host Management

What We've Learned Updated: 1.	many hosts in the host management view to be offline, but host lists dynamically created from the discovery queries seem to be accurate. The Host Management view can be manually cleaned up to give us a healthy baseline to compare results of future queries.
Steps to Reproduce Updated: Glenda will provisioning new servers so we can get a clean list of servers as a baseline.

Description Updated: Host lists are being updated by discovery queries, but the total host management list contains many outdated targets.  Some Host lists, which appear to be dynamic contain targets that are decommissioned.

--------
12/12/2024
--------
Host lists are being updated with new hosts but old hosts don't get cleaned up. I suspect this is intentional as a server not responding temporarily or being offline we wouldn't want it removed, but this may also be leading to some of our other issues. We discussed cleaning up the stale hosts manually, but decided I would like to keep them temporarily as we will be setting up a clean server with a new database and I would like the current environment as is for comparison in troubleshooting.

Description Updated: Host lists are being updated by discovery queries, but the total host management list contains many outdated targets.  Some Host lists, which appear to be dynamic contain targets that are decommissioned.

--------
12/12/2024
--------
Host lists are being updated with new hosts but old hosts don't get cleaned up. I suspect this is intentional as a server not responding temporarily or being offline we wouldn't want it removed, but this may also be leading to some of our other issues. We discussed cleaning up the stale hosts manually, but decided I would like to keep them temporarily as we will be setting up a clean server with a new database and I would like the current environment as is for comparison in troubleshooting.


--------
23/12/2024
--------
Installed and configured NEA host discovery on the new server. Verified that the discovery was running and working, Glenda followed up the following day and confirmed hosts were all discovered and the host list looked much better.

What We've Learned Updated: 1.	many hosts in the host management view to be offline, but host lists dynamically created from the discovery queries seem to be accurate. The Host Management view can be manually cleaned up to give us a healthy baseline to compare results of future queries.

--------
23/12/2024
--------
Installed and configured NEA host discovery on the new server. Verified that the discovery was running and working, Glenda followed up the following day and confirmed hosts were all discovered and the host list looked much better.

Checked on errors generated during the file system scans. No immediately alarming errors are present and most seem to point to a know access issue with a new server. Migrated the database and log files on the database server to the correct drives and verified access. Verified that AIC is seeing information and could still access information after DB migration. Setup Active Directory job, we expect this to fail as we were not able to fully configure it but this will help point us to any possible problems that may exist.

Final job migrations are complete. AD jobs are running and appear to be working as expected. SQL jobs are setup and will run overnight and we will check on their status in the next meeting. A new license has also been provided that we will apply in the next meeting. Licensing for Ad permissions module does not appear to exist for eglin. They have jobs setup to run this module but it has been failing for quite a while now. I have requested the account manager for eglin look into getting them a license for this as Glenda has stated she would like to use this.

SQL Issues are resolved except for one remaining server that was misconfigured and Glenda cannot login to. FWVMIT - port not opened on firewall, SQLExpress was using high number port instead of default 1433FWVMLLA1 - SQL service is not enabled on IPv4 so all connections were rejectedITM2SQLDB - Firewall was only allowing specific IPs to connect, added NEA server IP to the list. waiting for after hours service rebootFWVMIT3 - No user permissions or access, SA is disabled and only local users have permissions. File servers are all scanning and seem to have no errors, monitoring for 60 days to make sure retention is working as expected. host cleanup is done and host list looks correct.

SQL connectivity issues are solved to all but 2 servers. Glenda is checking on getting access to these servers to fix the permissions. FWVMEXPRESSOCVMWJA Several jobs show they ran with no errors but have empty data. I suspect this is normal for these jobs but I need to look into them. SQL_PermissionChangesSQL_ActivitySQL_SensitiveDataActivity One job is throwing an odd access error that needs to be investigated. SQL_PasswordIssues

What We've Learned Updated: 1.	many hosts in the host management view to be offline, but host lists dynamically created from the discovery queries seem to be accurate. The Host Management view can be manually cleaned up to give us a healthy baseline to compare results of future queries.

--------
23/12/2024
--------
Installed and configured NEA host discovery on the new server. Verified that the discovery was running and working, Glenda followed up the following day and confirmed hosts were all discovered and the host list looked much better.

--------
17/01/2025
--------
Glenda confirmed host list looks good and we even have some new hosts discovered that she did not know about. This case appears to be done but we will monitor while working on other cases.
Next Steps Updated: Monitor host lists.

On call with Glenda today we were still attempting to push NAM upgrades. All accounts get rejected even though they have full permissions and testing using powershell shows the accounts have permissions to push file and execute them on remote servers.Glenda believes her team found what is causing the issue and will update once they have it resolved. KB article may be needed for the error seen as it only appears in one other ticket and the solution did not work here.

Created a two new tickets for Glenda, one to detail the NAM migration and another for NAM not showing all activity she expects to see.The activity monitor console cannot upgrade the agents on remote systems due to some security block that neither Glenda or I can determine. I was able to test pushing the agent through powershell and the install succeeded. I have created a script for Glenda to run that will automate pulling the host info from the Agents.ini file and will use this to push agents to servers through powershell.  #Netwrix Activity Monitor Remote installation #1.0 Ian Ranstrom $oldPolicy = Get-ExecutionPolicySet-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted -Scope Process$hosts = @()$credentials = Get-Credential -Message "Please enter credentials for an account with access to all systems"  Function naminstall {   param(       $computername,       $creds   )   $session = New-PSSession -ComputerName $computername -Credential $creds   Copy-Item -Path "C:Program FilesNetwrixActivity MonitorConsoleAgentsx64SBFileMonAgent.msi" -Destination "C:WindowsTempSBFileMonAgent.msi" -ToSession $session   Invoke-Command -Session $session -ScriptBlock{       C:WindowsTempSBFileMonAgent.msi /qn   }} Write-Host "Building host list" Get-Content "C:ProgramDataNetwrixActivity MonitorConsoleAgents.ini" |ForEach-Object {   if ($_ -match "HOST"){       $hosts += $_.SubString(5)       }   }foreach ($h in $hosts){   Write-Host "Installing agent on $h"   naminstall -computername $h -creds $credentials} Set-ExecutionPolicy $oldPolicy -Scope ProcessWrite-Host "Install complete"

Glenda does not want to resolve the installation through script any longer. She wants to use this time to try and diagnose why the agent could never upgrade even in previous upgrades.I was able to look at the logs a little deeper and the error that we found on the FWVMIT server and I don't think this is an NTLMv1 issue. In my internal labs I was able to disable NTLMv1 and the agent pushed successfully. However I did find this from Microsoft when I looked up the error code.   Error Code Description 0xC0000064 The username you typed does not exist. Bad username.  Looking at the Activity Monitor logs I see this for the username.  "Domain":null,"UserName":"SBSVC"  I think that the target machine is trying to authenticate locally instead of to the domain.Glenda is going to try updating the FWVMIT to use the domainusername format and see if this corrects the issue.
Title: nwxcorp.my.salesforce-sites.com

Body: Steps to Reproduce Updated: Servers appear to be working as expected. Monitoring during other tickets to ensure servers are populating as expected.
